material_source_passage: Although current commercial silicon solar cells can reach 10-20% power conversion efﬁciency (PCE), current solar cell manufacturing processes require high temperatures, vacuum technologies, and high-grade materials, all of which increase cost. As a result, current commercial solar cells remain expensive compared to fossil fuels, around 25-50 cents per kilowatt hour in the USA [1].
property_source_passage: Although current commercial silicon solar cells can reach 10-20% power conversion efficiency (PCE), current solar cell manufacturing processes require high temperatures, vacuum technologies, and high-grade materials, all of which increase cost. As a result, current commercial solar cells remain expensive compared to fossil fuels, around 25-50 cents per kilowatt hour in the USA [1].
value_source_passage: Although current commercial silicon solar cells can reach 10-20% power conversion efficiency (PCE), current solar cell manufacturing processes require high temperatures, vacuum technologies, and high-grade materials, all of which increase cost. As a result, current commercial solar cells remain expensive compared to fossil fuels, around 25-50 cents per kilowatt hour in the USA [1].

material_source_passage: Silicon has dominated the solar cell market since the ﬁrst crystalline silicon solar cell was reported to have a 6% power conversion efﬁciency by Chapin in 1954 [8].
property_source_passage: Silicon has dominated the solar cell market since the ﬁrst crystalline silicon solar cell was reported to have a 6% power conversion efﬁciency by Chapin in 1954 [8].

material_descriptor:
Schottky junction device
Thin-film transistors
Solar cells
Nanocrystal size 10-20 nm
Devices were fabricated by the spin-cast method
Silicon nanocrystalline thin films were spin-cast onto indium tin oxide-coated glass substrates and aluminum on the top of the film
material_source_passage: The thin-ﬁlm formation process was based on Si NCs without any ligand attachment, exchange, or removal reactions. The Schottky junction device showed a photovoltaic response with a power conversion efﬁciency of 0.02%, a ﬁll factor of 0.26, short circuit-current density of 0.148 mA/cm<sup>2</sup>, and open-circuit voltage of 0.51 V.
property_source_passage: The thin-ﬁlm formation process was based on Si NCs without any ligand attachment, exchange, or removal reactions. material_descriptor:
Schottky junction device
Thin-film transistors
Solar cells
Nanocrystal size 10-20 nm
Devices were fabricated by the spin-cast method
Silicon nanocrystalline thin films were spin-cast onto indium tin oxide-coated glass substrates and aluminum on the top of the film
material_source_passage: The thin-ﬁlm formation process was based on Si NCs without any ligand attachment, exchange, or removal reactions. The Schottky junction device showed a photovoltaic response with a power conversion efﬁciency of 0.02%, a ﬁll factor of 0.26, short circuit-current density of 0.148 mA/cm<sup>2</sup>, and open-circuit voltage of 0.51 V.
property_source_passage: A scheme of the device architecture is shown in Fig. 1. To fabricate Si NC Schottky junction devices, Si NC thin ﬁlms were spin-cast onto indium tin oxide (ITO)-coated glass substrates at 700 rpm in a glove box. To obtain the 250-nm Si NC thin ﬁlm, several spin-coating steps were required. After Si NC deposition, devices were completed by the deposition of 100 nm of aluminum on the top of the ﬁlm as the electrode. The active area of each device was 0.046 cm 2.
value_source_passage: A scheme of the device architecture is shown in Fig. 1. To fabricate Si NC Schottky junction devices, Si NC thin ﬁlms were spin-cast onto indium tin oxide (ITO)-coated glass substrates at 700 rpm in a glove box. To obtain the 250-nm Si NC thin ﬁlm, several spin-coating steps were required. After Si NC deposition, devices were completed by the deposition of 100 nm of aluminum on the top of the ﬁlm as the electrode. The active area of each device was 0.046 cm 2.

Devices were fabricated by the spin-cast method

material_source_passage: The thin-ﬁlm formation process was based on Si NCs without any ligand attachment, exchange, or removal reactions. The Schottky junction device showed a photovoltaic response with a power conversion efﬁciency of 0.02%, a ﬁll factor of 0.26, short circuit-current density of 0.148 mA/cm<sup>2</sup>, and open-circuit voltage of 0.51 V.
property_source_passage: The incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) for the Si NCs-only device is shown inFig. 3b. As to be expected from the relatively poor performance of the device, the IPCE is relatively small with a maximum of <sub>~</sub>4% in the ultraviolet.
value_source_passage: The incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) for the Si NCs-only device is shown inFig. 3b. As to be expected from the relatively poor performance of the device, the IPCE is relatively small with a maximum of <sub>~</sub>4% in the ultraviolet.

material_source_passage: Figure 4 demonstrates that the Si NC ﬁlm shows strong absorption only in the blue and ultraviolet range of the spectrum. While the Si NCs used here have a band gap only slightly larger than the Si bulk band gap of 1.1 eV, the absorption in the red-to-green range of the optical spectrum is poor. This is a consequence of the Si NCs still behaving as indirect band gap semiconductor material, a behavior that only breaks down once the Si NC size becomes smaller than <sub>~</sub>2.5 nm [11].
property_source_passage: Figure 4 demonstrates that the Si NC ﬁlm shows strong absorption only in the blue and ultraviolet range of the spectrum. While the Si NCs used here have a band gap only slightly larger than the Si bulk band gap of 1.1 eV, the absorption in the red-to-green range of the optical spectrum is poor.
